head.title: Metal Strip in Crash Wasn't Concorde's

identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Manufacturing, Operations and Logistics

hedline.hl1: Metal Strip in Crash Wasn't Concorde's

abstract.p: French transportation ministry says that metal strip that punctured tire on Concorde that crashed outside Paris on July 25 was apparantly part of another plane; investigators believe chunks of burst tire created fuel leak that caused left-side engines to shut down (S)

block.p: The French minister of transportation said today that a metal strip that punctured a tire on the Concorde that crashed north of Paris on July 25, killing 113 people, was apparently part of another plane.

The minister, Jean-Claude Gayssot, made the statement on the Europe One radio station. Officials in his ministry and at the French Bureau of Accident Investigations emphasized that the source of the 16-inch strip of metal had not been definitely identified, but that it was not part of the Concorde.

The French minister of transportation said today that a metal strip that punctured a tire on the Concorde that crashed north of Paris on July 25, killing 113 people, was apparently part of another plane.

The minister, Jean-Claude Gayssot, made the statement on the Europe One radio station. Officials in his ministry and at the French Bureau of Accident Investigations emphasized that the source of the 16-inch strip of metal had not been definitely identified, but that it was not part of the Concorde.

Investigators believe that chunks of rubber from the burst tire tore through the Concorde's wing, producing a fuel leak and fire that caused both left-side engines to shut down and the aircraft to crash.
